subject: Re: A convention to be kept?
msgSnippet: Just a little comment on the use of the apostrophy in German. It is ALWAYS incorrect to use an apostrophy before a plural s and before a genetive s. Uschi s
messageBody:
Just a little comment on the use of the apostrophy in German. It is
ALWAYS incorrect to use an apostrophy before a plural s and before a
genetive s. "Uschi's Frittenbude" and the like is wrong orthography.
However, the authorities decided to let it pass as it has now become
so farspread as to be inextinguishable. But this generosity only
applies to the false "saxon genetive" in German (which does not
exist). Öpart from sis, wei not öplei dscherman orsogrefi to inglisch?
Wann wudd feineli noh hau tu pronauns se inglisch wörds.

Cheers,
Hermann Philipps

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tim_rice09" <tim_rice09@...> wrote:
>
> Forgive me if I phrased that in a confusing way. "POTATO'S 3¤"
> will hopefully never be correct. The day it does will be the day
> German rules are applied to English. How about "ihtsch" for each?
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Wayne Cornelius"
> <wayne_cornelius@> wrote:
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tim_rice09" <tim_rice09@>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > >
> > > The apostrophy works well in T.O. to show the difference
> between
> > > plural, possesive and plural possesive case. It was recently
> pointed
> > out
> > > to me that even in phonetic writing it would still be usefull.
> In the
> > > Quickscript manual it is used in abbreviations like he'd and
> he'll
> > > though I am yet to find a place where it marks plurals.
> >
> > Using apostrophes to mark PLURALS isn't supposed to be done
> in /any/
> > English writing! It's grammatically improper (see "Greengrocers'
> > apostrophes" in your search engine).
> >
>
